Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: The Processes of Coalescence and Colonialism

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The researchers, at the University of Arizona and collaborators at Desert Archaeology, Inc., will collect data to understand the relationship between the social processes of coalescence and colonialism. Previous research on both of these processes has tried to understand how the communities created through either coalescence or colonialism maintained social cohesion, both within pluralistic communities and between communities in a diverse social landscape. At large scales, one of the primary impacts of both coalescence and colonialism was to draw communities together in a web of economic interdependence, whether on equal footing or in unequal relationships. In many parts of the world, and particularly in North America, coalescence was a key process shaping the social landscape into which European colonists inserted themselves. The organization of economic relationships in these coalescent societies may have served as a pattern for the economic relationships created by the subsequent colonial encounter. However, the relationship between these processes has been understudied. How much did economic organization under European colonialism rely on existing relationships among Native American communities created through coalescence? To what degree did European colonialism reconfigure these existing relationships? Understanding the functioning of these processes is broadly relevant to understanding the history of modern Native American communities in the United States, particularly in the U.S. Southwest, Great Lakes, and Southeastern regions. The results of this research are also applicable more generally to understanding how economic interdependence can foster cooperation between communities and help manage some of the social challenges encountered in highly diverse communities.

The researchers will explore the relationship between pre-colonial coalescence and early colonialism in the Americas, particularly the impact of both processes on economic organization. This research will focus on the degree of continuity and change in the organization of the regional economy of New Mexico from a period of coalescence (A.D.1300-1598) into the period of early Spanish colonialism (A.D.1598-1700). Data will be collected from archaeological sites dating to this period throughout the Rio Grande valley of central New Mexico. This data collection is necessary to fill geographic gaps in the existing archaeological literature and therefore give a more complete picture of economic relationships between communities throughout the Rio Grande in New Mexico. The researchers will compile existing data from three lines of evidence to evaluate different scales and types of economic interaction related to the production of ceramics. The researchers will collect new data through petrographic analysis of ceramic tempers and isotopic analysis of lead glaze paints to help fill geographic gaps in the coverage of the existing data. Network analysis will be use used to analyze the data and will both facilitate comparison between the lines of evidence and provide a methodology for understanding complex sets of relationships at larger scales. The researchers will generate new methodologies for archaeological network analysis of regional interactions. The researchers will also expand on existing network analyses of coalescence to also help evaluate the social consequences of colonialism.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Archaeological coalescence refers to the social process whereby a number of distinct communities rapidly nucleate, coming together to form a smaller number of denser and more diverse communities which are often held together by new social rules and organization. This process has been investigated archaeologically worldwide, but is of special interest in the archaeology of Indigenous societies in North American prior to European colonization. In much of the east coast of North American, and in the U.S. Southwest, coalescence significantly reshaped Indigenous societies in the centuries prior to the first European colonization efforts. As such, understanding how Indigenous Pueblo societies in the U.S. Southwest responded to and influenced Spanish colonialism in the 17th century requires a better understanding of the social structure of coalescent Pueblo societies in the preceding centuries.

This project makes use of archaeological ceramic data to investigate both coalescent and colonial Pueblo social structure in the period between A.D. 1200 and A.D.1700, particularly for the eastern Pueblos along the Rio Grande in New Mexico. This project makes use of the methods of social network analysis to extrapolate some elements of social structure from different kinds of ceramic data. These different types of data include traditional archaeological typologies of ceramics, isotopic analysis of lead used to make the glaze paint distinctive of the primary decorated ceramic type in the study period and region, and petrographic analysis of crushed rock used to temper ceramic vessels. Each type of data provides evidence of related but distinct social networks of ceramic production and consumption, which themselves reflect other social relationships.

Work to date has produced two major results. First, network analysis comparing the Western Pueblo region (Arizona and west-central New Mexico) with the Eastern Pueblo region (along the upper and middle Rio Grande in New Mexico) has identified the century between A.D. 1400-1500 as particularly transformative for the structure of social networks in both regions. Among the Eastern Pueblos, social networks expanded significantly in the period after A.D. 1450, integrating diverse communities at a large, regional scale. In contrast, social networks in the Western Pueblo region during the same time period increasingly contracted, replacing long-distance interaction with increasingly local interaction. The structural distinction between Eastern and Western pueblos persists into the early Spanish colonial period (A.D.1598-1700), indicating that while Spanish colonialism may have had severe impacts on Pueblo people, the structure of ceramic production and exchange was not one of the areas significantly impacted.

The second major result of this project stems from additional analyses of lead glaze paint and crushed rock temper from the major decorated ceramic type used in and produced by Rio Grande Pueblos during the study period. This project extended analysis of these materials in prior work from other parts of the Eastern Pueblo region to the previously under-studied middle and lower Rio Grande regions. Analysis shows that, while relationships among different sub-regions and communities within the Eastern Pueblo region increased after A.D. 1450, some sub-regions were less well connected than others. In particular, communities in the lower Rio Grande consistently tapped into different resources for ceramic production than other regions. Communities in the lower Rio Grande did not generally participate in the social networks which distributed rare resources used in ceramic production, like lead ore. This data reveals the complex structure of the social networks which distributed ceramics and raw materials for ceramic production. This complexity contrasts with, but does not contradict, the overall pattern and trajectory revealed by the first analysis. A third and final analysis will synthesize both of these elements of the project to understand where and how different social networks related to ceramic production and consumption do and do not overlap, contrasting the structure of each different type of network.
